channel.name: Example zk proof from bank account

messages.content: I am looking for guidance or an example implementation on how to generate and validate a zero knowledge proof that a bank transfer of value X was executed from a person.
You can hash the bank transfer transaction using Poseidon hash and use it as a private input: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/tutorials/private-inputs-hash-functions

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content: thank you for your reply, but hashing would mean losing all data
let's say I need to verify that you sent $5000 to Mr Lucas Doe, IBAN CY12110001101...
What do you mean loosing all data? It’s a hash data that you  can verify onchain
in the date range 11-15/06/2023
Yeah but explain loosing all data?
hashing is a one way function

unless I also hash the data, doing something like 
`user_hash == sha256(recipient+amount)`

but then I have the variable input of the date range, I guess the user can send it in cleartext as an addendum

`user_hash == sha256(recipient+amount+timestamp)`
You can also use Struct that add the fields of your transactions. And hash them together. I suggest using Poseidon which is SnarkyJs friendly
how do I know the data comes from a reliable source?
I could fork the frontend of my bank and display random data
change hosts to mask the url

That’s a great questions, maybe you can use Oracle that can check this bank transaction? Also depends on your use case, does the verifier has access to this transaction or the possibility to check balance orso?
I mean technically a few banks expose APIs so one could use those
but I was hoping zk could offer a better solution

Well it’s privately only for the one that can access his own transaction right. Somehow you need a source that you trust this could be a bank API. But you don’t have to reveal all data. You could also implement a secret only reveal a signature to your verifier.
This video is a great example how you can says that you know a secret without revealing the secret it self: https://youtu.be/fOGdb1CTu5c

embeds.title: Computer Scientist Explains One Concept in 5 Levels of Difficulty |...
embeds.description:
Computer scientist Amit Sahai, PhD, is asked to explain the concept of zero-knowledge proofs to 5 different people; a child, a teen, a college student, a grad student, and an expert. Using a variety of techniques, Amit breaks down what zero-knowledge proofs are and why it's so exciting in the world of cryptography.

Amit Sahai, PhD, is a profe...

messages.content: the problem is banks
they have very diverse APIs
integrating them all would become a problem, that is where ZK could be helpful somehow

For example in my use case. I’m building zk keyless wallet. And I’m saving the hashes of guardians in Merkle tree. So if a user wants to use a guardian, I check offline storage and the hash of this tree is the selected guardian is verifiable onchain
In you case you can build up a transaction Merkle tree somehow..
Great use case thou..
it's all so weakly coupled tho
I was bought into the idea that you could get off-chain data on-chain without an oracle and zk tech would somehow prove that it is valid and comes from a reliable source
It could be possible, maybe someone else can give you insights on this..
https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/tutorials/oracle

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content: https://tlsnotary.org/#How
this is what I meant
oracles are a terrible solution, they require custom adapters for all different integrations and maintenance. Zk tech is able to solve that, like in the example above

Basicly you could do the same with ZK smart contract . You need smart contract that puts hashes of trx to Merkle Tree that is trusted by 2 parties (User which has API key and can see every data) and Trusted party that signs your Merkle tree base on your proof
same as TLS notary, the trusted party can't see the data, but base on ZKP he knows the user API is correct maybe by showing part of data that can be verify
Or you don't need User interaction as in EU Legalisation, a User can approve a Trusted party to see part of the API which they can verify and approve onchain
Like balance before / balance after transaction should be ok
You can connect as a PSD2 service provider and ask approval from user, here is an example : https://doc.bunq.com/
Architecture example how you can do it
If the trx hash is on Merkle tree, it's easy to show other this: "let's say I need to verify that you sent $5000 to Mr Lucas Doe, IBAN CY12110001101..."
without revealing any information about you or your trx
You can DM me to have deep conversation about this, I've been playing with PSD2 API for years 😛

As for now Open Bankin API doesn't have a trx hash to query, but you see everything within the trx: https://openbankinguk.github.io/read-write-api-site3/v3.1.11/resources-and-data-models/aisp/Transactions.html. What you can do maybe build ZK Gateway as client only (without backend), while the user do a request, the Gatekeeper doens't save any trx to the backend services
I know PSD2 but it's so poorly implemented
TLS notary would allow to bypass that by leveraging the existing SSL infrastructure of webservers
this is what the zkoracle stuff does IIRC
issue with this is you need to support every bank separately
yes correct, while with TLS notary you just need the bank frontend to use SSL
This is neat, would be interesting if the notary can run as a zkapp
